label: 404. Madame Baptiste to Bp Patrick Lynch -- April 6, 1866
description: Madame Baptiste writes to Bishop Patrick Lynch about recent inquiries concerning the burning of Columbia and their convent during the war and asks the Bishop for permission to publish their account of the events. April 6, 1866. 4p.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value: A.M.D.G Ursuline Convent & Acadmey "Valle Crucis"--near Columbia S.C. April 6th 1866 My dearest Brothers, Revd Dr Meriwether arrived safely at home this evening & gave us the pleasing intelligence of your good health, & pleasant enjoyment of the Rector's visit with the Genls A & S around the Bay. Mrs. Cory [?] wrote us, that you were to give confirmation in St. Mary's on Sunday, or we would have expected you back with Dr. M. I was particularly anxious to consult you about the publication of our manuscript concerning "the burning of our convent"-- I told you before, about Genl Hill writing to me for an account of it-- & perhaps the Rector told you of Dr. Trezevants visit requesting [In left hand margin in longhand] All send aff & very grateful respects, beg your prayers & benedictions--especially your own Sister Ellen. Sr. Baptista I am so much gratified that the Rector told you he was pleased with his visit here. Write soon & come if you can conveniently[End Page 1] us to give a statement as to how we got possession of the "Preston Place" & saved it--which statement will be published. Today I received a message from professor LeConte of S.C. College, asking for the same. I did the amiable to them all, & unless you will correct & revise our manuscript & have it printed, others will have us in print anyway. Genl Preston offers to print it for us in April, but I cannot accept his offer without your consent & I would be sorry to do anything that would [illegible] against religion or the future interests of our convent. You know that when Abp Purcell gave me such "a slap in the face" about Sherman & Hampton, I [illegible][End Page 2] enclosed him the pamphlet "sack & burning of Columbia" by Simms. He seems to have been staggered a little by it & sent it on to Capt Cornyn [?] (the commissary who gave us rations & $50 in greenbanks.) for corroboration, he however answers it I think evasively & his letter has been published in the "Cincinnati Telegraph," the Abp's organ-- & is now going the rounds of the papers South I am told. I believe Mr. Cornyn [?] to be a man of undoubted probity & yet his statements are not true. I suppose thro' ignorance. The subject has become so agitated, that a certain set of respectable citizenry will attest to the fact of Columbia having been burned by the army under Sherman-- & our account is[End Page 3] to be a sort of corroborative evidence, together with that of a hundred others. I feel some timidity about this. For Dr. Trezevant, I have had simply my letters to Mrs. Dr. Darby (Miss Mary [illegible] Preston that was)-- & Genrl John L. Preston's letters to me written-- since he only wants to prove, that that house--private property, was ordered to be burned. They are all very warm on the subject just now-- & it is really wonderful to me, that an attestation is required of a thing as plain as that the sun shining--! If you cannot come up to Valle Crucis & go to Cheraw also I suppose I must sacrifice the pleasure of seeing you to our dear Parents--Anna will hardly be able to travel so soon & I should think not for some time. John telegraphs--she is not so well--he cannot be at home before Saturday. You can hear quicker than we from Cheraw. I feel anxious about Anna.[End Page 4]
